Yes, there are several mindfulness practices that are well-suited for children in schools. Here are a few examples:

1. Mindful breathing: This practice involves paying attention to the breath as it moves in and out of the body. It is a simple and effective way for children to calm their minds and bodies.

2. Body scan: This practice involves paying attention to different parts of the body, starting at the top of the head and moving down to the toes. It can help children become more aware of their bodies, relax their muscles, and release tension.

3. Mindful movement: This practice involves moving the body mindfully, such as through yoga, tai chi, or simple stretches. It can help children become more aware of their bodies, improve flexibility, and build strength.

4. Mindful listening: This practice involves paying attention to sounds in the environment, such as the sound of a bell or a bird singing. It can help children focus their attention, improve listening skills, and become more aware of their environment.

5. Loving-kindness meditation: This practice involves cultivating feelings of love and kindness towards oneself and others. It can help children develop empathy and compassion, and improve their relationships with others.

These practices can be adapted to suit different age groups and can be integrated into the school day in various ways, such as during morning meetings, transitions between classes, or as a part of physical education classes.
